message.content: Yes, the authors conducted research with human subjects and mentioned that their user study was part of an IRB-approved study (Protocol No. 49406 reviewed by Stanford University). They also discuss the potential risks and benefits of their approach in the Broader Impact & Ethics Statement section of the appendix.

Yes, the authors mention that they recruited users on Prolific, a crowdsourcing platform to conduct research studies, as part of an IRB-approved study (Protocol No. 49406 reviewed by Stanford University). The paper does not explicitly discuss potential participant risks, but it does mention the precautions taken, such as wage estimates and average experiment times.

Yes, the authors conducted research with human subjects and mentioned the user study as being part of an IRB-approved study (Protocol No. 49406 reviewed by Stanford University). Potential risks of the approach and avenues to address them are discussed in the broader Impact & Ethics statement in the Appendix (Section A).
